generate_nickname_inputs.description: Calculates the optimal sequence of button presses to enter a given nickname on the Pokémon naming screen. It handles both uppercase and lowercase letters and minimizes cursor movement. The output is a list of lists, where each inner list represents one turn's worth of inputs (either a sequence of directional presses or a single action button).

nickname.description: The desired nickname, up to 10 characters.

history.commit_message: feat: Create nicknaming automation tool. This tool, `generate_nickname_inputs`, automates the tedious and error-prone process of entering a Pokémon's nickname. It calculates the optimal button presses to navigate the on-screen keyboard for any given name, saving significant time and preventing manual input errors. This is a major quality-of-life improvement.

fix: Refactor output to a list of lists. The tool previously generated a single, mixed list of directional and action inputs, causing system truncation. This update changes the output to a list of lists, where each inner list contains either a sequence of directional moves or a single action button. This allows for sequential, per-turn execution, preventing input errors and making the tool functional.

fix: Correct keyboard layout and cursor logic. The tool's internal representation of the keyboard was incorrect, causing it to select the wrong characters. This update corrects the data structure to match the in-game layout and revises the cursor tracking logic to correctly assume the cursor moves to the opposite case-switch button after a change, improving accuracy.

fix: Correct cursor movement logic for non-grid keyboard. The previous version assumed a uniform grid for the nicknaming screen, causing incorrect horizontal movement calculations on rows of different lengths. This led to the cursor landing on the wrong key and prematurely ending the naming process. This commit refactors the movement logic to use modulo arithmetic for horizontal movements, correctly calculating the shortest path with wrapping on each individual row, and adjusts the cursor's column position after vertical movement. This ensures accurate cursor positioning and prevents future nicknaming failures.

list_reachable_unseen_tiles.description: Finds all unseen tiles that are reachable from the player's current position using a Breadth-First Search (BFS) on the traversability grid. Returns a list of coordinates.

history.commit_message: feat: Create list_reachable_unseen_tiles tool. This tool uses a Breadth-First Search (BFS) to identify all unseen tiles that are adjacent to the currently reachable area. This will provide a comprehensive list of all potential exploration paths, allowing for more strategic decisions about where to explore next, fulfilling a need identified during a system-prompted reflection.

debug: Add print statements to diagnose BFS failure. The tool is failing to find any explorable paths in Ilex Forest, returning an empty list when unseen tiles are clearly visible and adjacent to the player's reachable area. This update adds debug prints to show the number of tiles visited by the BFS and the number of border tiles found. This will help determine if the BFS is prematurely terminating or if it's correctly concluding that no valid border exists from the starting position, which would indicate a flaw in the map data or the tool's grid population logic.

This will help diagnose whether the BFS is failing to explore the map correctly or if the border detection logic itself is flawed.

refactor: Remove debug print statements. The debug trace confirmed the tool is working correctly and the pathing failure was due to the player being in a dead-end section of the map, not a bug in the tool. This commit cleans up the code.

debug: Add verbose BFS tracing to diagnose pathing failure. The tool is incorrectly reporting no reachable unseen tiles in a major city, which is a critical failure. This update adds per-node logging to the BFS loop to get a complete execution trace, which is necessary to identify why the algorithm is failing to find obvious exploration paths.

fix: Confine BFS to seen tiles. The tool's BFS was incorrectly traversing unseen tiles, causing it to explore the entire map data instead of just the visible area, and thus failing to find any 'border' tiles. This commit modifies the grid population logic to correctly treat unseen tiles as impassable, confining the search to the known map and fixing the critical failure.

fix: Revert incorrect impassable logic. The tool was failing because a previous 'fix' incorrectly treated unseen tiles as impassable in the main grid. This prevented the BFS from ever reaching the border of the seen area. This commit removes the `or is_unseen` condition, restoring the grid to only reflect true obstacles and allowing the BFS's own logic to correctly handle the seen/unseen distinction.

fix: Re-apply correct impassable logic for unseen tiles. The tool was failing because the BFS was allowed to traverse unseen tiles, causing it to explore the entire map data instead of just the visible area. This commit correctly re-adds the `or is_unseen` condition to the grid population logic, ensuring unseen tiles are treated as impassable and confining the BFS to the known map, which is the correct behavior for finding border tiles.

feat: Create BFS-based tool to find reachable unseen tiles. The main `find_path_to_target` tool is failing in a way that is difficult to diagnose. This new tool uses a simpler BFS algorithm to definitively identify the border of the known, traversable map. This will serve as a critical diagnostic to isolate whether the pathing failure is due to incorrect grid population or a flaw in the A* search logic.

fix: Correct BFS logic for finding unseen border tiles. The previous version incorrectly treated all unseen tiles as impassable within the traversal grid itself, which confined the BFS to the known area and prevented it from ever reaching the border. This commit refactors the logic to separate the concept of a tile being 'seen' from it being 'traversable'. The new BFS now correctly explores all reachable *seen* tiles and, from their edges, identifies adjacent *unseen* tiles as the border. This resolves the critical failure where the tool would return an empty list even when unseen tiles were visibly reachable.

find_path_to_target_bfs.description: A BFS-based pathfinding tool to find a path from a start to a target coordinate. Rebuilt from a working BFS implementation for better reliability. If the target is impassable, it will find a path to an adjacent tile.

history.commit_message: feat: Rebuild BFS pathfinder from a working base. The previous BFS pathfinder was fundamentally broken. This new version is built by adapting the proven BFS implementation from the 'list_reachable_unseen_tiles' tool. It includes basic one-way ledge handling and is expected to be much more reliable for navigation.

fix: Correct coordinate system handling. The tool was using 1-based indexing for coordinate validation while the map data is 0-indexed, causing 'out of bounds' errors for valid coordinates like y=0. This commit updates all boundary checks to use correct 0-based logic (e.g., `0 <= coord < max_dim`), resolving the critical pathing failure.

fix: Correct `FLOOR_UP_WALL` traversal logic. The tool was generating invalid paths by attempting to move in directions other than 'up' onto `FLOOR_UP_WALL` tiles. The previous logic incorrectly blocked upward movement instead of allowing only upward movement. This commit corrects the condition to ensure the pathfinder respects the one-way nature of these tiles, preventing future pathing failures.

fix: Implement correct one-way ledge traversal logic. The tool was generating invalid paths by attempting to move against the direction of `LEDGE_HOP_` tiles (e.g., moving up a `LEDGE_HOP_DOWN`). The previous logic incorrectly blocked valid moves instead of invalid ones. This commit corrects the conditions to ensure the pathfinder respects the one-way nature of these tiles, preventing future pathing failures.

fix: Correct coordinate system handling. The tool was failing because it mixed 1-based coordinates from the XML map data with 0-based indexing for the internal grid. This commit refactors the entire script to consistently use 0-based coordinates for all internal logic (grid population, pathfinding, boundary checks) by converting 1-based XML and input coordinates at the beginning and converting the final path back to 1-based for the output. This resolves the critical bug that caused it to generate invalid paths through impassable tiles like HEADBUTT_TREEs.

fix: Correct syntax error in one-way tile logic. The previous commit introduced a syntax error by having an unclosed parenthesis around the long conditional for checking one-way tile traversal. This commit wraps the entire boolean expression in a single set of parentheses, which resolves the `SyntaxError: '(' was never closed` and makes the tool functional again.

feat: Add adjacent tile pathing for impassable targets. The tool now checks if the target coordinate is an obstacle. If it is, the BFS goal is updated to find the shortest path to any valid, traversable, non-diagonal tile adjacent to the original target. This prevents pathing failures when the destination itself cannot be stepped on (e.g., an NPC, tree, or sign) and makes the tool significantly more robust for general navigation and interaction planning. Also refactored path reconstruction to be part of the main BFS loop for simplicity.

debug: Add verbose logging to diagnose pathing failure. The tool generated a path through a WALL tile at (27, 23). This commit adds targeted print statements to stderr to inspect the generated obstacle grid around the problematic area and to log the specific check that allows the invalid move into the path. This is a diagnostic step to identify the root cause of the failure.

fix: Treat unseen tiles as impassable. The pathfinder was incorrectly generating paths through unseen areas, which is invalid behavior. This commit modifies the grid population logic to mark any tile with `seen=\"false\"` as an obstacle, confining the search to the known map area.

fix: Correct syntax error in one-way tile logic. The previous commit introduced a syntax error by having an unclosed parenthesis around the long conditional for checking one-way tile traversal. This commit wraps the entire boolean expression in a single set of parentheses, which resolves the `SyntaxError: '(' was never closed` and makes the tool functional again.

fix: Correct syntax error in one-way tile logic. The previous commit introduced a syntax error by having an unclosed parenthesis around the long conditional for checking one-way tile traversal. debug: Add verbose logging to BFS loop. The tool is generating invalid paths through obstacles defined in `object_locations_json`. This adds logging inside the main BFS loop to trace the grid value check for each neighbor, which will help diagnose why the impassable tile check is failing.
